rsbNotes.title: Ps 18
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 18 The psalm thanks the Lord for a great deliverance. The same psalm appears in 2 Sam. 22 with minor differences.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:16
rsbNotes.text: 18:16 many waters. Symbolic of trouble and distress (Ps. 69:2).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:19
rsbNotes.text: 18:19 broad place. This may be an allusion to the Exodus and the conquest of Canaan. God delivered Israel from many waters (Red Sea) and brought them to a broad place (the Promised Land). The broad place contrasts with a narrow one, from which it would be hard or impossible to escape from an enemy.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:21
rsbNotes.text: 18:21 ways of the Lord. God’s covenant law.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:25
rsbNotes.text: 18:25 merciful . . . show yourself merciful. The term translated “merciful” has reference to God’s special lovingkindness toward those with whom He is in covenant relationship.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:27
rsbNotes.text: 18:27 you save a humble people. A constant teaching of the Old Testament and the Psalms, most notably Ps. 113:7–9.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:29
rsbNotes.text: 18:29 against a troop. A glimpse at the original inspiration of the verse. It appears as if the psalmist is waging war.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:30
rsbNotes.text: 18:30 the word of the Lord. His revelation to His people. Since this is a psalm of David in a warfare setting, perhaps the reference is more specifically to 2 Sam. 7, the Davidic covenant, where God promises to be David’s Father and God.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:31
rsbNotes.text: 18:31 but the Lord. The use of these rhetorical questions is emphatic: there is no one like the Lord (Ex. 15:11).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:34
rsbNotes.text: 18:34 bow of bronze. Bows were constructed primarily of wood, at times reinforced with metal. The bronze bow is meant to suggest the psalmist’s God-given strength.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:36
rsbNotes.text: 18:36 my feet did not slip. Paths are narrow and rocky in Israel permitting slipping and injury to a soldier. The divinely enabled, steadfast faith of David is illustrated.
